item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.description:
Hi Jason,
to be honest, I have no idea. I know you need SQL Server 2012 for the fancy BI features, but I'm not sure what happens when you mix different SQL Server editions. You better consult with an actual SharePoint expert on this.
item.content:encoded:
Hi Jason,

to be honest, I have no idea.
I know you need SQL Server 2012 for the fancy BI features, but I’m not sure what happens when you mix different SQL Server editions. You better consult with an actual SharePoint expert on this.

item.title: By: Jason
item.dc:creator: Jason
item.description: If I have a farm that has SP2013 with a SQL 2008 R2 backend, can I still get the proper 2013 BI components installed if I install a new web app and the SQL components using a separate SQL2012 SP1 box?
item.content:encoded: If I have a farm that has SP2013 with a SQL 2008 R2 backend, can I still get the proper 2013 BI components installed if I install a new web app and the SQL components using a separate SQL2012 SP1 box?

item.title: By: Waqas

item.description: Had to prepare a demo for Management, followed your blog and everything works great. A big big thank you.
item.content:encoded: Had to prepare a demo for Management, followed your blog and everything works great. A big big thank you.

item.title: By: Arne
item.dc:creator: Arne
item.content:encoded:
Hi Koen,
I’ve followed your blog and finished successfully. Bu got a big problem making a BISM connection in PowerPivot gallery. The problem arises at verifying the connection and using it for Powerview. Tried several solutions, but none successfully.
Situation:
+ No domain
+ SPFarm is administrator, can access all databases RDMBS an SSAS
+ Stopped “Claims to Windows Token Service” and restarted IIS
Any ideas?
Arne

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.description: The multiple server set-up is definately harder to do than a single server set-up, especially security wise. Since it's just a simple demo enviroinment I'd like to share with colleagues on a usb stick, I opted for the single server environment.
item.content:encoded: The multiple server set-up is definately harder to do than a single server set-up, especially security wise. Since it’s just a simple demo enviroinment I’d like to share with colleagues on a usb stick, I opted for the single server environment.

item.title: By: Peter Schott
item.dc:creator: Peter Schott
item.description: I was planning on just using a lot of the pre-configured images to handle the majority of the heavy lifting as I have this linked to an MSDN account. I think I'd still need to upload a Sharepoint ISO, but not 100% sure about that. Also not sure if I should try to configure this as a single server or use the more correct configuration of multiple servers. Seeing that you have this step-by-step for a single server, I'm leaning that way.
item.content:encoded: I was planning on just using a lot of the pre-configured images to handle the majority of the heavy lifting as I have this linked to an MSDN account. I think I’d still need to upload a Sharepoint ISO, but not 100% sure about that. Also not sure if I should try to configure this as a single server or use the more correct configuration of multiple servers. Seeing that you have this step-by-step for a single server, I’m leaning that way.

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.content:encoded:
@Peter: the principles of setting up a VM for Azure would be the same. Not sure about the domain controller though. I left it out, but you might include it for your VM in the cloud.

I’ve been meaning to test this out, but here in Belgium we have quite slow upload speeds, so uploading 40GB into Azure is a bit problematic.

item.title: By: Peter Schott
item.dc:creator: Peter Schott
item.description: Koen, would these instructions apply well to the Azure services using VMs? Any warnings if we want to set up a lab in the cloud?
item.content:encoded: Koen, would these instructions apply well to the Azure services using VMs? Any warnings if we want to set up a lab in the cloud?
